awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structure-borne Noise and Vibration Mitigation via Nonlinear Interactions in Phononic Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project aims at developing a new class of structural materials, also known as "phononic", whereby engineered nonlinear interactions suppress structure-borne noise and vibrations directly by manipulating the propagation of stress waves. This will be enabled by wave mixing effects inherent to the engineered nonlinear interactions that mimic phenomena observed at the atomic level. In transportation systems, structural components are susceptible to harsh mechanical environments, including vibrations, engine noise and aerodynamic/acoustic loads. The suppression of noise and vibration is highly critical, since it is associated directly with the long-term durability of mechanical/electrical components and the comfort level of passengers. Current techniques for noise reduction rely heavily on classical methods based on damping absorbers, such as soft foam, rubber wedges, and insulating blankets. While these methods are efficient in suppressing high frequency noise and vibrations, attenuation of low frequency components through a structure-borne path remains a formidable challenge. This research will contribute to the development of next-generation structural materials that are inherently capable of reducing structure-borne acoustic noise and rejecting unwanted vibrations in an efficient and controllable manner. From an educational standpoint, this project will attract young minds to science and engineering by enhancing their understanding of mechanical wave propagation through the "Catch a Wave" campaign.

This project involves designing, fabricating, and testing of a new type of engineered periodic lattices called "nonlinear phononic structures." These phononic structures will feature novel mechanisms that couple the propagation of different stress wave modes coherently. One example is a variable stiffness mechanism that leverages geometrical nonlinearities of thin-walled structures. These nonlinear phononic structures will naturally allow us to dynamically manipulate one stress wave mode via another, which is analogous to the working principles of electrical and optical energy flow devices (e.g., transistors). From a fundamental viewpoint, this project will shed light on the nonlinear wave dynamics of engineered lattice structures, leading to the discovery of new physical phenomena in terms of wave dispersion, disintegration, and scattering, unprecedented in conventional material systems and structures. From an engineering standpoint, the findings will open a new paradigm in filtering and mitigating structure-borne noise and vibration by dynamically controlling waves' speed, waveforms, and transmission gains.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Throughout this NSF CAREER project, we have conducted design, fabrication, and testing of various wave propagation media for the purpose of better handling structure-borne noise and vibration in mechanical systems. The energy transportation mechanisms discovered and investigated by the PI’s team offered an enhanced degree of freedom in controlling the dynamic responses of material and structural systems under harsh mechanical environments. The notable research outcomes obtained are: (1) Novel design of origami-based metamaterials; (2) Demonstration of wave guiding in topological metamaterials; and (3) Fundamental investigation of energy transport mechanisms in mechanical metamaterials. There are a number of additional key accomplishments by the PI’s team in the field of the linear/nonlinear wave dynamics in mechanical structures, such as discovery of breathers, nanoptera, turbulence-like energy cascading, resonance analogous to Ramsauer-Townsend mechanism, mechanical wave mixing effects, super-symmetry inspired isospectral wave transmission, and more recently rarefaction waves, to list a few.

These foundational research efforts contributed to the initiation and flourishing of novel fields of research, such as origami- and topology-inspired mechanical metamaterials. Collectively, these research accomplishments can be used for developing the next-generation of intelligent material systems and structures, which would efficiently and controllably absorb, redirect, and localize mechanical waves (i.e., sound and stress waves) for impact mitigation, vibration filtering, and energy harvesting purposes.

This NSF CAREER project enabled the PI to support several graduate students towards their Ph.D. degrees. It also helped training more than 10 undergraduate students (including 4 URM and female students) through the “Catch the Wave” campaign. The PI integrated the outcome of this project into his courses, such as Aerospace Structures, Composites, and Solid Mechanics courses. The findings of the project were reported in ~30 journal publications, and were disseminated to the scientific community by numerous technical presentations at professional meetings and invited talks delivered to prestigious institutes worldwide. Our research has also been featured in news media, such as Reuters, NSF News, and U.S. Public Broadcasting Service, which elevated the public interest in science and engineering (e.g., origami for science).


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Jinkyu Yang
